>If I'm mildly autistic (weird speech mannerisms, clumsy body language/motor skills) how much does my potential dating pool shrink because of this?
You need to get rid of this shit pronto. Humans are irrational creatures. They make decisions about whether or not they like you based on factors that aren't strictly logical. People don't decide whether they like you based on how good a person you are or the number in your bank account. It's all about how you make them feel when you're with them.

Strange mannerisms and clumsy body language mark you as a defective, and this will make people want to reject you on a deep, atavistic level. Their lizard brain goes, this is not someone I want in my tribe, this is definitely not someone I want to breed with. You'll be rejected no matter how good your other qualities are.

You need to work on making your mannerisms and bodily movements as "normal" as possible (without seeming like you're trying too hard). If your voice is weird, you might consider visiting a speech therapist. These small things make a big difference. They're crucial.

posts.sub: Life pro tips? So far I have discovered a few
posts.com:
1) Be part of a community, or two or three. I am an atheist, but I have always been involved in Scouting in my country and literally every person in my immediate family has gotten at least one job through connections made in scouting.
2.) Talk to, and be interested in old people. This is the fastest way to make people really like you.
3)Say yes to favors and ask other people for favors. Reciprocity is powerful tool.
4) Plan your day. Think about what you hope to do in depth. Think about every detail, every tiny little thing you have to do, including say, checking the traffic before you level, putting on your seat belt etc. Makes self control 100x easier. We all have things we know we should be doing, but getting up and doing them is a lot easier once you have thought each task methodically through, step by step.
5) Use social commitment/obligation. When I was studying from home I found it hard to get out of bed in the morning. However once I got a running partner I had no issues waking up, because I kew if I didn't I would be letting someone down.
Any one got any other good ones?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Step 1. Have marketable skills relevant to whatever kind of office work you are trying to get

Step 2. Bring up the major job board(s) in your country and pick out 3 entry level roles from the ads that might want to do and hold the required experience/qualifications for. Be sure to read the job ad thoroughly top to bottom. Take note of keywords and instructions.

Step 3. Write out a different cover letter for each position. It should be specific to the job ad amd the company. Research the companies, branch, hiring manager, etc. Write a first draft, then fix mistakes, then have someone proof then write a final. Each cover letter should take approximately a day to a day and a half to write.

Step 4. Write out your CV specific to each position. How you order things, what you emphasize, what you include and omit from your work history/education should be based on the specific role. Each resume should take about half a day to complete.

Step 5. Submit your applications following all instructions provided in their respective ads to the letter.

Those 3 positions should take the better part of 5 days. A full working week.

Step 6. Wait 4 days after the closing date for applications. If they have not contacted you, contact them to check on the status of your application.

Step 7. Rinse and repeat with a 1 week gap in between to allow for interviews.

posts.sub: In this thread we are going to look for the cure for depression
posts.com:
I have no proof or medical studies to show that this is the case, but I also have no doubts. I believe that to get out of depression, tiredness, fatigue and all that shit, you first have to work your body, since a healthy body is a healthy mind, for that it is good to do sports, whatever it is. it is as long as it keeps our body busy. Another important factor is studying, it doesn't really matter what, it doesn't matter if it's for university, school or for yourself, you have to do it to keep your mind occupied with something productive. I would also say that looking for a job, or generating income with a startup, as this will keep our mind and body busy, while giving us money, in itself gives us a reason to keep going, especially when you are working on something of your own.

Another important point is to stop comparing yourself to others, stop thinking that the other is better than you because you have more knowledge, money or physical condition. It is also very silly to think about issues such as superiority or inferiority, we are all human, we all have problems and difficulties in life, of course there are degrees of this, but this does not have to be a limitation. You have to focus on yourself, on your problems, on your virtues, on your life, and not on that of others.

Another issue is guilt and remorse, which depending on the person can be the easiest part, or difficult to overcome, because it is easy to forgive others, but sometimes it is difficult, if not impossible, to forgive yourself. No matter how dirty your hands are, they can always be cleaned. You have to accept your sins, accept what you did wrong and live with it. Go to a priest, a psychologist, or tell someone you trust what you did, this can help, it doesn't matter if you think psychology is a joke, or if you don't believe in God, the important thing is to somehow get the weight off What are you wearing.

posts.name: OP
posts.com: My least favorite part of this thread is going to a psychiatrist and being prescribed medication, which in itself sucks. But these in some cases are necessary to be able to do the above. posts.com: think you need to begin with the question of why do people in general feel emotions to begin to answer why someone would fall into a perpetual negative emotional state. Emotions are clearly intrinsic instincts not learned although learned experiences can change what triggers the emotions to occur. These instincts evolved over time to prod people towards the actions that have proven to be evolutionarily successful over time. Because people are highly social animals and there is fierce competition between different social groups of people, many of the emotions we feel are actually designed to not simply benefit yourself and improve your own survival, but to benefit the survival of the entire social group. These instincts go hand in hand with developed cultural mores.

It all comes down to conditioning.

From the most recent trigger or episode to your emotional trauma that sets off depression.
Or the cycle of trauma and pain you repeat and keep yourself in.
Down to traumatic events that have a lifelong impact on your psyche.

The necessary systems in place for recovery are 'safety', 'hope of recovery and future', an environment that fosters these two things as well as the social justice aspect, meaning you get the recognition of trauma you were dealt and the perpetrator dealt with. (but in the case of Act of God events, it's rationalisation through the reality of what happened)

This means, identifying things in your environment and social groups as well as your past, that negatively affect you. Doing your best to distance and remove those obstacles in your life and then having the 'stability' of an environment that is conducive to positive feedback cycles and a normalisation of ptsd behaviour responses in order to become and feel normal.

Lack of hope is another big reason, but this falls back to conditioning and a lack of positive feedback cycles fueling your worldview. If your metaphysical understanding of the universe is lacking, you won't see the point of your individualism in the big picture.
>seek god
>or develop another useful schema (evolution)


Depression is just when life beats you down and you lack the insight and motivation or opportunity to actually make a change. It's as simple as that.
And if you say your family has a history of depression, then that's just generational conditioning that has left your psyche disordered in order to grow somehow. Your ancestors fought through their environments to overcome depression, as should you etc.

My depression started when I was 13 years old, I didn't bathe, I had constant nightmares, I didn't eat, I was sad and with a feeling of emptiness all the time. I didn't really have any strong trauma, I lived a good life in general, but the fear of death, the fear of emptiness and knowing that everything we know would vanish, really terrified me, made me sad, and not wanting to do anything. I was very afraid of dying and leaving this world. But I don't know what happened that I saw how a car hit my brother and all those feelings left.
A couple of years later when I had made a good business, I went back into that fear of death, but do you know why that didn't last long? Because I had a project, I was going to do my first crop, I worked, I thought about how we could do things better, I learned, that really got me out of that state of anguish, fear, and emptiness. Then, of course, I went to do a sport, and took some medicine, and the truth was that they did me good.

As someone who has been through the psych treatment ringer, I think this is solid advice for most people.
Personally, medication has been life-changing for me. I don't think people should jump to medication though. I take Parnate, which is an MAOI. However, the road to getting the medication that I needed was extremely difficult. I had over 25 failed ECTs, a full course of ketamine therapy, TMS therapy, another MAOI that failed miserably (Marplan), antidepressants from every category imaginable, and who knows what else.
In my opinion, it's impossible to go wrong with the advice initially posted here. In my opinion, the road to finding effective psychiatric treatment is often counter productive anyway. Being kind to yourself is free.

>>28226302
We cannot say whether or not you should take antidepressants, you must attend one or two sessions with a psychiatrist and tell him about your problems, and he will determine whether or not you have depression. You can be a functional, charismatic person, who bathes, goes to work, studies, and does everything well, but if apathy (loss of interest in things), a feeling of emptiness, and physical symptoms such as fatigue from nothing , then you may have depression, especially with those suicidal thoughts that you have.
Therapy can also help, but if you go to several sessions, tell them all your problems and see that it doesn't help you, it's better to change someone better. Do not stay with the first option, if you do not like something you are always free to go and change.

posts.com: Going to start university in fall. I'm a total social sperg, so how to make the best out of it, find friends and a potentially a girlfriend?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28226354
Put actual effort into your first impression.
Super important to try and be social on the first day, first class, first opportunity or whatever it is. It's weird/hard to start making friends after like 2 months of having the same classes with people.
Don't try and drag out any conversation at all ever. Keep it short and sweet.
Steal jokes and phrases with no shame. Originality is overrated.
Just listen to people because most of them want to talk about themselves and about how cool they are.
You can usually ask someone like 3-4 questions about themselves, let them do all the talking, and that person will walk away feeling like they know you super well and you great at conversation or something.
Read how to win friends and influence people if you want actual advice.

posts.com:
I used to have a passion for mathematics, but my PhD experience was traumatizing. My advisor gave me poor advice that led to the failure of my research project, and my research papers were criticized and rejected by nearly everyone except my advisor who claimed to have a very positive opinion of his topic. One professor even told me to my face that I should have known better than to work on this project. The aftermath of my PhD made it difficult for me to find employment in mathematics and resulted in financial loss for my family. My mental health was severely impacted.

Recently, my advisor hinted that he may have been incorrect in his assessment of my project, and that I had potential as a student. However, this only fuels my bitterness. Some people tell me to get over it and move on, but I find it hard to move past my trauma and rekindle my love for math.

You should tell her and make her make her own decision on the status of the relationship.

It is difficult, and a heavy diagnosis probably kills your appetite for anything you ever hoped for, but there is no need to kill your life now and terminate every plan and potential because of a limiting factor.

If you are not dead yet, you still have time to make arrangements and to pursue.

My grandpa was diagnosed with a deadly condition when he was young and was told he only had months to live. He shut himself in for almost a year, stopped eating completely, fell into depression, and became a debilitated person who couldn't get out of bed. One day he gets a phone call and the doctor apologizes, saying that they gave him the wrong diagnosis and that he had no complications.

I am not saying that there is a chance that your diagnosis was wrong, but know that our mental frame is often more potent and impactful.

Don't kill yourself before your diagnosis does. Maximize your circumstances and use these limitations to work faster and check for every potential form of therapy, procedures and ailments to help limit and delay symptoms.

> continued disrespect, so decide to diss some back
> ultimate frisbee group is also /pol/ circlejerk, but when I make the tiniest reference I get daggers
> have a feeling group members hate me because of these reasons
> feeling confirmed by senior members who decide to boot me

I may have burned a bridge with her. But looking back, it was the journey, not the endgame. I learned more social skills during my short stay with them than I ever did before uni. I also have just started hanging out with the local fishing group (no ulterior motive, just want something to do on weekends other than vidya) since making backups has become the standard for me.

On a side note, I used to do research under horrible micromanagers, and since I got the feeling that they hated me. I was looking for a backup research group, and when they day came for the eventual firing from my quiet quitting, I was ready to go with my new research group. This new group is so much better, the project leads are awesome people to work with. I guess what I’m trying to say is that things will always get better, even if it may suck in the moment (this pressure can be relived with good backup plans).

Also there is always someone hotter. Humanity looks average because we fall for those that look average and reproduce with said people, if you can only have one takeaway from this, this is it.

>>28225489
Get some topical cream containing Tretinoin. It doesn't have to be the brand in the pic but aim for 0.05%, it can also be as strong as 0.1% but that is really powerful stuff so I would stick to 0.05%.

Just rub it in and forget about it but I also apply sunscreen to layer the skin because it will become sensitive to daylight.

Normally this is prescribed but dermatologists and pharmacies don't just hand these out so I resorted to the Grey Market. To OP and any others reading this, it was well worth a try.

Some Pros:
Handles every and any form or pus/acne/boil etc
Fast acting
Unnoticable and not painful long term

Some Cons:
Pricey
Can be tricky to get from pharmacy or prescription
Can only deal with treated areas (won't target the whole body unless you rub it all over which is not recommended at all)
Once area is treated, need to wait for skin to heal before assessing results.

https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-3956/tretinoin-topical/details

posts.sub: The social interval
posts.com:
It's crazy that all I needed to be in a relationship, to have had sex, to maybe even have kids by now, was to just be alittle bit more socially aware at those younger years in middleschool and highschool.
If I just didn't ignore, one word responded, ghosted or just stared at girls talking to me until they left it all would have been fine.
By an interval of like 4 years I learned enough social skills to be able to succeed with the women from those 4 years ago. Even though my social skills were always far below my peers at any given moment, to have caught up with this interval at any point was all I needed to do.

Example: At 17 I knew what I should have said and done at 13. At 22 I knew about all the chances I missed on my way to age 18, at 26 I learned about the chances I had at between 18 and 22, and so on.

At the age of 26 I had basically unconsciously turned down 9 advances from women throughout the years. All of these situations would have lead to some kind of relationship if I just knew what was going on and how to proceed.
Like I said, I didn't need to be good at any of the social games and norms that most people find natural, I just needed to catch up with the interval and it would have been fine and I never did.

The scary thing now at 31 is I haven't had any of these revelations since age 26.
I have to guess it's because I interact with women so sparingly nowdays and that I just haven't got enough new experiences to reflect on to receive any kind of revelation.
Perhaps the interval have increased and I'm in for a big suprise in a few years and will know of even more missed opportunities.
It doesn't feel the same anymore at age 31. The only women I interact with are clients from work. I work in service (massage therapy) with no co-workers. It's almost impossible to decipher any clients, in case they imply double meaning. If I interpret their body language or wording to mean anything outside of the context of my work I will just be a douchbag and a creep.

>>28101536

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28101153
A job change isn't going to fix your life. You need an entire lifestyle change. I'm 26 and went through something similar around 24. I'm going to recommend something cliche, but it fucking works for reasons I will elaborate on. Get in shape. If you are fat lose weight. If you are skinny hit the gym. Yes it's a physical thing but we are mostly after the mental benefits. When you improve physically it does several things mentally (arguably it has more mental benefits than physical). First is you learn to be disciplined. This obviously effects every aspect of life. You need discipline to escape NEETdom. Next it will give you a taste of that "better life". You will see hard effort turn into tangible rewards that you can be proud of. This can set off a chain reaction into other aspects of life you feel are lacking. Next is confidence. You will be more confident in your self and your abilities and it could be enough of a boost to get you to pounce on opportunities you otherwise would have missed by being passive. Perhaps most important of all it will get you out of the house and give you a hobby that isn't doing anything for you. This can lead to meeting new people and gives you a common interest hobby that you can share and engage with most people over. Don't forget other people will treat you better too.

All of that doesn't even take into account the physical aspects that also play a role in mental health. You would likely see an increase in certain hormones such as testosterone and a decrease in things like estrogen. These hormones play a huge role in mental health and having screwed up hormones probably play a huge role in depression and the like. In my opinion physical improvement is the number one best thing you can do if you are unhappy with your life because it lays the foundation for everything else. This is coming from someone who was fat basically my entire life and was well on my way to being an eternal neet. Getting /fit/ is what saved me.

>>28176244
I can't read it. My specific situation will not really relate to you.

The TL;DR is that I am an /out/ist through and through and nothing is going to change that.

I was in the army before college. Biology degree. Wildly depressed, and medicated for it. In college I did an internship with a conservation agency and it was fun, but I did the "right thing" and after school I just kept pursuing my "career path." Nothing glamorous or financially enticing, mind you. At 27 I had a paradigm shift, some major life changes (sister offed herself and ended a toxic 6 year relationship) and I took some seasonal /out/ work in Alaska to try and clear my heart and my head. Quit taking Zoloft during this time.

Following this, I left and did a "normal" job for about 1.25 years before I again felt the urge to get the fuck back outside. I worked for an environmental compliance contractor. I had a moment of clarity when a guy who had been there for 12 years told me he had a zoology degree. It made me sad to know he once shared my dreams. So I had to leave. Almost every person I knew told me that, at ~28 it was too late for a "career change" and I should just stay in place and effectively work at the same place until I died. I've since worked for a few different agencies/places for the feds doing /out/ things. I do not make much money. My job security is tenuous. But I feel at peace and wouldn't change it.

The point of my story is simply that if you recognize something you are truly passionate about, you should just stick with it, because trying to convince yourself you are happier in some other capacity just results in you being miserable. I wouldn't do something just to feel like you're moving forward, if that makes sense. I wouldn't do something you aren't "super passionate" about. Do not go be a cop simply because it is SOMETHING. Its your life, anon. 1/4 of it is over. Do you want to waste another 1/2 doing something you don't even give a shit about?

The general rule is that if you were in the latter group, you would know by 25 ie you would already have been grinding for years at that point and you'd start to see success. Sorry to say, that's not you, so on to step two.

Step two is employment, which mostly sucks. Some people will tell you about how they have a passion for making other people rich, but they're mostly just coping. The purpose of employment is to GET CASH FLOW so you can either exit employment or at least have the funds to cope with it and stay sane. You should find something you're good at that you can tolerate without burning out that MAXIMIZES cash flow and pursue that. Ideally it should pay you to learn skills that you can deploy outside of employment so you can exit employment sooner rather than later. Think of employment as a bridge from virgin neetdom to chad neetdom. Some examples of viable options are trades, sales, it, coding meme, internet marketing. You can get an entry-level job in most of these fields with little-to-no experience. Grind certs, lie, just do whatever you need to do. Then start accruing skills that you can use for freelancing, consulting, contracting, ect in order to exit employment. If you really want to you can do your art fag stuff on the side, and if that blows up and you stop showing up to your job, more power to you.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28223542
Gotta make peace with your circumstances, anon. It's easy to consider all the things you're missing, have missed out on, the things you loathe about your company and your surroundings. The truth is, that never changes either. You'll always view things that way if you don't intentionally change your perspective. You could have all you feel you're missing, all you currently dream of having, and, once you get there, you'll find new reasons to be miserable. Happiness or contentment are tough, but they're not products of your circumstances, they're things obtainable to anyone willing to work for them, and are almost entirely matters of mindset, rather than of objective or tangible factors. You have to take control of what you can control, make peace with the rest, don't carry bitterness or loathing about your shortcomings, and just get on with it bud. Do what you can every day to do better, to get where you want to go, keep your expectations within reality, be forgiving of yourself, others, life, the world, and look for the good in all things. Recognize that your perspective is from an infintesimally minute point of reference, and you are but a part of a greater whole, more meaningful and magnificient than whatever is possible in a single lifetime. Chill out, don't take it so hard. Life is short, suffering is temporary, just have some fun.

We can argue about whether there's a constructed direction set about by a being greater than the whole, or whether it's a random series of events culminating into a biological arms-race to which we are the latest inheritors of the throne as Apex, but regardless of the means or the ends what is certain is that from nature both predators and prey have been adapted to suit specific purposes, for which particular traits have risen to the top and stood the tests imposed upon them, and for predators many of those traits relate to lethality. Humans are predators, and in spite of our "soft" focuses on ethics, our body is made to kill, our body requires death to sustain it, and we are the best adapted in existence to kill. In fact, enjoying the act itself could be more "optimal" to our adapted design than feeling remorseful, and so, in real terms, what we would consider sociopathy may be "good" from a particular perspective, and humanitarianism could be "bad", if you need those qualifiers to order the world by. War can also be "positive", depending upon your defined expectations of positivity, as challenge gives rise to adaptation, making us more capable of both inflicting harm and defending from it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28224493
I'm not OP, I was just jumping in to nitpick the use of optimal. It seems we agree that it depends how you measure it. I just disagree that this subjectivity means you rationally *shouldn't* care, because that in itself is another value judgement.

>I don't intend to offend, but this reads as incoherent to me; if you can clarify your meaning
You were appealing to natural selection finding "optimal" solutions/structures. This is either very close to circular reasoning (assuming whatever nature does is optimal) or relies on some axiomatic value to measurable optimize.
Since you were very clear that OP's ideas on morality were "anthropomorphizing", I assumed you were making the argument that "nature is as it must be", or something like that.

But I'm pointing out that natural selection, either of organisms or processes, only needs to be *locally* optimal. It just means that the current way the world works manages to keep itself going along more or less the same road better than similar alternatives. It doesn't mean that there aren't other possible ways for organisms or societies to exist--it only means that transitioning from the current dynamic to a different, just-as-stable one (say, a "humanitarian" society which somehow has altered the environment to make malice completely maladaptive) must be enormously difficult/unlikely.

A lot of the work was just keeping things presentable so if I checked on a bathroom and there was no shit or toilet paper on the floor then I wouldn't bother cleaning. Do you know which area of your hospital you'll be working on? Is it the ED or an inpatient floor? are you morning or night shift? Clinical psych major
Thats going to depend a lot on the source, of which there are many.
First make sure youre eating well, hydrated, getting enough sun, activity, not too sedentary, have community etc..
Next tell your doctor and get your biochemistry checked.

Depressive state is a mood with a biological function. Exercise isnt going to do fuck all for you if your problem in the first place wasnt due to lack of it.

There are even cases of treatment resistant depression being well.treated by advil. There is no one answer. You have to generally monitor and care for your health and work wirh your doctor and get your blood checked for things.

D deficiency, B12 Deficiency, iron deficiency, hypothyroidism.. just a few examples of things thatll cause low moods and depressive states only a blood test can find.

Its an overall health thing. Not just gym shit. Theres a huge problem where people dont understand just how complex and multivariabled these things are, experience a depressed rut, start jogging, and that works for them, then they come online wnd spam "gotta lift bro" like thats the cause all fix all.
Doesnt work like that.

Find. The. Source.

You see, you are wired to give in to the same stupid impulses all the time which is why you do the same stuff all the time.

I've eaten beans cheese and chips every week for the last year out of pure habit. I always say I'm going to get started doing what I'm supposed to be doing but our dopemine in our brain tells us things are different.

Like I started learning Japanese but the issue is that my brain is hardwired to think Japanese = hentai, thus I started thinking about hentai constantly while practicing kanji flashcards. So my every thought while I was studying was about hentai to some degree. As soon as I put it down for a while it just kinda disappeared mostly.

So our learned associations are really ingrained in us and it's very hard to get rid of. Spending time changing some of these things is helpful to get into more comfortable life decisions. It's hard to say whether or not adapting to a new trait is a good idea though. If we changed constantly we wouldn't live stable lives and would end up in trouble a lot.

People are justified in rejecting others for any reason as long as there isn't a prior commitment involved.
Sometimes a rejection can be irrational (for example, they jumped to a false conclusion after misunderstanding something you said), but even then, they still have the unilateral right to reject.

"Body count" per se is irrational to reject someone over (as if there's any real difference between having 5 sexual partners or 6, or any way for someone to restrain themselves to stay within your arbitrary rule before even meeting you), but what it *attempts* to reject isn't irrational. It's a value judgment against promiscuity, and rejecting someone for not sharing your values is an entirely reasonable thing to do.

If you're not married, you've probably done exactly the same thing as many of these "hedonists", just fewer times/with fewer people. Sex without commitment. Your main point, that those people are disgusting, isn't wrong, but their behavior is enabled--even encouraged--if it's only deemed wrong after being done an arbitrary number of times.
If someone is expected to have sex while dating, then merely by following what you expect of them, they will become anathema to you. What is someone to do if they fail to find a spouse after 3 tries? Move the goalposts and find someone whose "slut number" is 4 instead of 3, since everyone has their own arbitrary idea? It's almost always the latter in practice, and this is why we have reached the current point in society.

>>28223957
Marriage literally is the commitment. It is an institution by which people commit to spend their lives with each other (in practice, imperfect, but discarding the *idea* of such an institution because retards have managed to devalue it only makes things worse).

> I would say being together 10 years unmarries requires more commitment
This is "commitment" in the sense of personal intent to do something. Which is obviously important for a good relationship, but it's unknowable until after it's already happened. This is useless for guiding behavior. Mixing these meanings only devalues commitment in practice, since it removes obligation.
Having a formal commitment of marriage is the most consistent way to serve the ideal of monogamy (one lifetime partner). Not only is it a way to enforce it--something impossible if "commitment" is just a personal feeling that can be unilaterally changed--but you would presumably only agree to such a commitment if you ALSO felt committed. Plus, as an institution, the standard is *consistent*. As in, it is a very simple way to ensure that people have similar values and goals, much simpler than pretending that whatever informal arrangement you have will end perfectly (even though that's wrong more often than not).

Legitimizing sex outside of marriage destroys that standard, to the detriment of anyone who values what the standard upholds: true, lifelong, monogamy. Even controlling for religiosity, people who wait both divorce less and have happier marriages. And their first partner is far more likely to be their only partner.
